Institute for Social and Economic Research</AuthEnty>       </rspStmt>       <prodStmt>         <copyright>Copyright Institute for Social and Economic Research</copyright>         <fundAg>Economic and Social Research Council</fundAg>       </prodStmt>       <distStmt>         <distrbtr>UK Data Service</distrbtr>         <depositr>University of Essex. Institute for Social and Economic Research</depositr>         <depDate date="2009-09-16T00:00:00Z">16 September 2009</depDate>         <distDate date="2009-09-23T00:00:00Z">23 September 2009</distDate>       </distStmt>       <verStmt>         <version date="2014-01-23T00:00:00Z">3</version>       </verStmt>       <holdings URI="http://dx.doi.org/10.5255/UKDA-SN-6290-2" />     </citation>     <stdyInfo>       <subject>         <keyword>1991</keyword>         <keyword>1992</keyword>         <keyword>1993</keyword>         <keyword>1994</keyword>         <keyword>1995</keyword>         <keyword>1996</keyword>         <keyword>1997</keyword>         <keyword>1998</keyword>         <keyword>1999</keyword>         <keyword>2000</keyword>         <keyword>2001</keyword>         <keyword>2002</keyword>         <keyword>2003</keyword>         <keyword>2004</keyword>         <keyword>2005</keyword>         <keyword>2006</keyword>         <keyword>2007</keyword>         <keyword>2008</keyword>         <keyword>2009</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/ad78d78e-6267-460b-af47-8b8bc1c5c587">ADMINISTRATIVE AREAS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/ab95dd9d-9ba3-4e5a-8147-bdab25d6c86f">GEOGRAPHICALLY REFERENCED DATA</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/58fca0a1-16b9-46f5-9cc4-bda17e90b1e3">HOUSEHOLDS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/4a821930-5499-4bb4-b058-ab0ae3c8746b">UNITED KINGDOM</keyword>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The main <i>British Household Panel Survey</i> (BHPS) is conducted by the <a href="http://www.iser.essex.ac.uk/ulsc/" title="ESRC UK Longitudinal Studies Centre">ESRC UK Longitudinal Studies Centre</a> (ULSC), together with the <a href="http://www.iser.essex.ac.uk/" title="Institute for Social and Economic Research">Institute for Social and Economic Research</a> (ISER) at the University of Essex. In addition to conducting the BHPS and disseminating it to the research community, ISER undertakes a programme of research based on panel data, using the BHPS and other national panels to monitor and measure social change. <br> <br> The main objective of the BHPS is to further understanding of social and economic change at the individual and household level in the UK, and to identify, model and forecast such changes and their causes and consequences in relation to a range of socio-economic variables. It is conducted as a longitudinal study, where each adult member (aged 16 years and over) of a sampled household is interviewed annually. If individuals leave their original household, all adult members of their new households are interviewed. Children are also interviewed. For full details of the BHPS methodology, sampling, changes over time, and a complete set of documentation, see the main BHPS study, held at the UK Data Archive under SN 5151. <br> <br> <b>BHPS geographic identifiers</b><br> The BHPS geographic identifier data are consistent with the ONS Postcode Directory (ONSPD). Users are advised to obtain the latest version of ONSPD from the <a href="http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/geography/products/postcode-directories/-nspp-/index.html" title="National Statistics Postcode Products">National Statistics Postcode Products</a> webpage, where it is downloadable in text (.txt), CSV, Microsoft Access or .dbf formats, or can be ordered on CD/DVD.<br> <br> <br> <b>Understanding Society:</b><br> From Wave 19, the BHPS has been subsumed into a new longitudinal study called <i>Understanding Society</i>, or the <i>United Kingdom Household Longitudinal Study</i> (UKHLS), conducted by ISER. The BHPS Wave 19 formed part of <i>Understanding Society</i> Wave 2 (January 2010 - March 2011). The BHPS fieldwork period has therefore moved from September-April to January-March. This means that the gap between interviews 18 and 19 for the BHPS sample ranges between 16 and 30 months rather than the standard 12 months. From Wave 2, the BHPS sample has been a permanent part of the larger study and interviews are conducted annually again. BHPS sample members have an identifier within the <i>Understanding Society</i> datasets, allowing BHPS users to match BHPS Wave 1-18 data to <i>Understanding Society</i> Wave 2 (and onwards) data. <i>Understanding Society</i> is held at the Archive under SN 6614. Further information is available on the <a href="https://www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/" title ="Understanding Society">Understanding Society</a> web site.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract>The <i>British Household Panel Survey, Waves 1-18, 1991-2009: Conditional Access, Area Classification for Output Areas (OAC)</i> dataset contains OAC geographic variables for each wave of the BHPS to date, and a household identification serial number for file matching to the main BHPS data. This dataset is subject to restrictive access conditions, different to those for the main BHPS: see Information box on the right or Access section below.<br> <br> For the third edition (January 2014) revised geographic data files for each wave have been deposited. The documentation has also been updated.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Variables include household identification number and OAC codes for matching with each wave of the BHPS to date.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="1991-01-01T00:00:00Z">1991</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2009-01-01T00:00:00Z">2009</collDate>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>Output Areas</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Families/households</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Administrative units (geographical/political)</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Respondent households included in the main BHPS.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Data are collected annually</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>GfK NOP</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>Office for National Statistics</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency</dataCollector>         <sampProc>See the main BHPS for details of sampling.</sampProc>         <collMode>Transcription of existing materials</collMode>         <collMode>See the main BHPS for details of data collection.</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>OAC data are not weighted. See the main BHPS for details of weighting used.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Special licence required</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage.<br/>Additional special conditions of use also apply. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.  In addition, the UK Data Service is required to request permission from the depositor prior to supplying the data.<br/><br/>Please note:<br/>Since these data pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence they have additional special conditions attached to them that take the form of a Special Licence (SL). The SL requires the completion of an additional application form, agreement to the conditions of the SL, the signature(s) of the researcher(s) and the institution(s) with responsibility for the researcher(s), and the explicit permission of the data owners to release the data to the researcher(s). This is to ensure that the guarantee of confidentiality given to survey respondents is protected. SL applications are screened by the UK Data Service and the data owners and data are only released to those researchers requiring data for statistical research purposes and who can justify their need for the SL data.<br/><br/>Researchers are required to keep the data under conditions of greater security than required under the standard End User Licence. The guide, <a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/ukda171-ss-microdatahandling.pdf' >Microdata handling and security: guide to good practice</a>, explains how to meet these conditions.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>         <conditions><b>Conditional access information:</b><br/> Registered users can access any one of the BHPS Medium-level Geographical Identifiers files after agreeing to click-use conditions prior to ordering the data.<br/> Only where users wish to obtain a second (or third etc.) BHPS Medium-level Geographical Identifiers file are they also required to complete a Special Licence Access request.</conditions>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>
